title: China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) donated J$22Million to the Jamaican National Premier League (Linked with project #72019).
description: On August 28th 2012, China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd. (CHEC) donated J$22 million (250,000 USD) to the Jamaican National Premier League. The Jamaican National Premier League is the top division for men's football (soccer) in Jamaica. According to Jennifer Armond, CHEC's communications manager, the donation was made "to reach to the hearts and pockets of the young men that live in the communities who enjoy playing and watching the sport." The donation was utilized to maintain the welfare of football clubs across Jamaica. Linked with project #72019, a donation of awards that China made to the Premier League on the same date. Not to be confused with project #70720, a similar donation made by CHEC the following year.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) donated J$22Million to the Jamaican National Premier League (Linked with project #72019).

# Description
On August 28th 2012, China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd. (CHEC) donated J$22 million (250,000 USD) to the Jamaican National Premier League. The Jamaican National Premier League is the top division for men's football (soccer) in Jamaica. According to Jennifer Armond, CHEC's communications manager, the donation was made "to reach to the hearts and pockets of the young men that live in the communities who enjoy playing and watching the sport." The donation was utilized to maintain the welfare of football clubs across Jamaica. Linked with project #72019, a donation of awards that China made to the Premier League on the same date. Not to be confused with project #70720, a similar donation made by CHEC the following year.
justification: Project is a donation to support sports and community development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation to Jamaican National Premier League for football club welfare, social development focus

title: China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) establishes an award for the Jamaican National Premier League (Linked with project #70723).
description: On August 28th 2012, China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd. (CHEC) established the the "CHEC Star Baller of the Month" award, which includes a package of 30,000 dollars. The donation is available to players in the Jamaican National Premier League. With the typical premier league season running from September to March, the transaction value was calculated by multiplying 30,000 by 7. Some of the recipients during the 2012-2013 season were Fabian 'Ding' McCarthy and Jermie Lynch. This league is the top division for men's football (soccer) in Jamaica. According to Jennifer Armond, CHEC's communications manager, the donation was made "to reach to the hearts and pockets of the young men that live in the communities who enjoy playing and watching the sport." The donation was utilized to maintain the welfare of football clubs across Jamaica. Linked with project #70723, a flat monetary donation to the Jamaica National Premier League.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC) establishes an award for the Jamaican National Premier League (Linked with project #70723).

# Description
On August 28th 2012, China Harbour Engineering Co., Ltd. (CHEC) established the the "CHEC Star Baller of the Month" award, which includes a package of 30,000 dollars. The donation is available to players in the Jamaican National Premier League. With the typical premier league season running from September to March, the transaction value was calculated by multiplying 30,000 by 7. Some of the recipients during the 2012-2013 season were Fabian 'Ding' McCarthy and Jermie Lynch. This league is the top division for men's football (soccer) in Jamaica. According to Jennifer Armond, CHEC's communications manager, the donation was made "to reach to the hearts and pockets of the young men that live in the communities who enjoy playing and watching the sport." The donation was utilized to maintain the welfare of football clubs across Jamaica. Linked with project #70723, a flat monetary donation to the Jamaica National Premier League.
justification: Project is a social development initiative focused on sports and community engagement without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation to Jamaican National Premier League, focus on community welfare and sports development

title: China's CHEC donates US20,000 to Jamaica's Olympic Team (Linked to project #72027)
description: In August 2012 China Harbour Engineering Company handed over US$20,000 to the Jamaica Olympic Association in support of the Jamaican athletes in their 2012 London Olympics Games competition, according to a Jamaica Observer article. The donation was followed up by a J$2 million donation for a celebration following the athletes' return (see project #72027).
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China's CHEC donates US20,000 to Jamaica's Olympic Team (Linked to project #72027)

# Description
In August 2012 China Harbour Engineering Company handed over US$20,000 to the Jamaica Olympic Association in support of the Jamaican athletes in their 2012 London Olympics Games competition, according to a Jamaica Observer article. The donation was followed up by a J$2 million donation for a celebration following the athletes' return (see project #72027).
justification: Project is a donation to support sports and athletes, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation to Jamaica Olympic Association, support for athletes' competition and celebration

title: China's CHEC donates J$2 million to Jamaica's Olympic Celebration Concert (Linked to project #72025)
description: Following the 2012 London Olympic Games, China Harbour Engineering Company spent $2million Jamaican Dollars to help fund a celebration ceremony for the returning athletes. The celebration took place in Jamaica's National Arena from October 13-15, 2012. This project is linked to #72025, where CHEC also helped to fund the Jamaica Olympic Association outright.

title: CHEC donates J$13 million to Jamaican Office of Disaster Preparedness for Hurricane Sandy relief
description: On November 9th, 2012, China Harbor Engineering Company (CHEC) donated J$13 million to the Jamaican Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM) to be used for disaster relief. The money was to assist people and schools that suffered damages from Hurricane Sandy, and went to ODPEM’s Hurricane Sandy Emergency Relief Fund. The donation was presented by CHEC Caribbean region general manager, Zhongdong Tang to the director-general of ODPEM, Ronald Jackson.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
CHEC donates J$13 million to Jamaican Office of Disaster Preparedness for Hurricane Sandy relief

# Description
On November 9th, 2012, China Harbor Engineering Company (CHEC) donated J$13 million to the Jamaican Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM) to be used for disaster relief. The money was to assist people and schools that suffered damages from Hurricane Sandy, and went to ODPEM’s Hurricane Sandy Emergency Relief Fund. The donation was presented by CHEC Caribbean region general manager, Zhongdong Tang to the director-general of ODPEM, Ronald Jackson.
justification: Project is a humanitarian donation for disaster relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation for Hurricane Sandy relief, funds directed to emergency relief fund for affected people and schools

title: Chinese Government donates equipment to help Syrian refugees living in Jordan
description: On November 14, 2012, China handed over 240 caravans, lamps, torches, and large-sized tents to the Jordan Hashemite Charity Organisation to help Syrian refugees in Jordan. Chinese Ambassador to Amman Yue Xiaoyong and Vice Secretary-General of the Jordan Hashemite Charity Organisation Rajab Ramadan Zubeidah signed documents during the handover ceremony.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title
Chinese Government donates equipment to help Syrian refugees living in Jordan

# Description

Chinese Ambassador to Amman Yue Xiaoyong and Vice Secretary-General of the Jordan Hashemite Charity Organisation Rajab Ramadan Zubeidah signed documents during the handover ceremony.
justification: Project focuses on humanitarian aid without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of caravans, lamps, torches, and tents for Syrian refugees

title: Chinese Government pledges RMB 15 million grant for Syrian refugees living in Jordan
description: On August 23, 2012, the Government of China made a commitment to grant the Government of Jordan CN¥15,000,000 for refugee relief. The aid was intended to respond to civil unrest in Syria and provide emergency humanitarian aid to Syrian refugees in Jordan and Lebanon. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) reported that China's contribution remains in the commitment phase. This project is captured by UNOCHA flow #97525.  The 15 million RMB donation to Lebanon is captured in project ID #41523.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government pledges RMB 15 million grant for Syrian refugees living in Jordan

# Description
On August 23, 2012, the Government of China made a commitment to grant the Government of Jordan CN¥15,000,000 for refugee relief. The aid was intended to respond to civil unrest in Syria and provide emergency humanitarian aid to Syrian refugees in Jordan and Lebanon. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UNOCHA) reported that China's contribution remains in the commitment phase. This project is captured by UNOCHA flow #97525.  The 15 million RMB donation to Lebanon is captured in project ID #41523.
justification: Project is focused on humanitarian aid and refugee relief, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Emergency humanitarian aid for Syrian refugees, grant for refugee relief

title: Xinjian Corps of Armed Police Grant Martial Arts Training Course for the Jordanian Public Security Directorate
description: On November 27th, 2012, members of the Jordanian Public Security Directorate (PSD) demonstrated skills learned during a martial arts training course coached by members of the Xinjiang Armed Police Force. The Jordanian PSD invited cooperation with Chinese police and received training from five Chinese policemen as martial arts coaches from November 3, 2012, to December 19th, 2012.  At the graduation ceremony Jordanian PSD members demonstrated learned skills such as boxing, stick fighting, Taichi, and enemy apprehension.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Xinjian Corps of Armed Police Grant Martial Arts Training Course for the Jordanian Public Security Directorate

# Description
On November 27th, 2012, members of the Jordanian Public Security Directorate (PSD) demonstrated skills learned during a martial arts training course coached by members of the Xinjiang Armed Police Force. The Jordanian PSD invited cooperation with Chinese police and received training from five Chinese policemen as martial arts coaches from November 3, 2012, to December 19th, 2012.  At the graduation ceremony Jordanian PSD members demonstrated learned skills such as boxing, stick fighting, Taichi, and enemy apprehension.
justification: Project involves martial arts training for law enforcement, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Martial arts training course, cooperation between police forces, focus on skill development

title: CPPCC donates computers, printers, and scanner to the Office of the Jordanian Prime Minister
description: On May 21, 2012, the Vice Chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, Wang Gang, signed a "symbolic" technical grant to the Office of the Jordanian Prime Minister, Dr. Fayez Al-Tarawneh. The grant included 100 computers, 50 printers, and 50 scanners, valued in total at 1,000,000 Jordanian dinars. The grant took place after a meeting concerning Jordan's future investment climate between the Jordanian Prime Minister and the Chinese representative.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
CPPCC donates computers, printers, and scanner to the Office of the Jordanian Prime Minister

# Description
On May 21, 2012, the Vice Chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, Wang Gang, signed a "symbolic" technical grant to the Office of the Jordanian Prime Minister, Dr. Fayez Al-Tarawneh. The grant included 100 computers, 50 printers, and 50 scanners, valued in total at 1,000,000 Jordanian dinars. The grant took place after a meeting concerning Jordan's future investment climate between the Jordanian Prime Minister and the Chinese representative.
justification: Project involves donation of office equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of computers, printers, and scanners to government office, no energy-related components

title: China Eximbank provides $1.13 billion buyer’s credit for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#54798, #54797 and #85185)
description: On December 29, 2011, Atyrau Refinery LLP — a project company and subsidiary of Kazakh state-owned KazMunayGas — signed an EPC turnkey contract for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project (also known as the Advanced Oil Refining Complex Construction Project and the Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Construction Project) with a consortium of contractors consisting of Sinopec Engineering Group (SEG), Marubeni Corporation, and JSC OGCC KazStroyService. SEG was the leader of the consortium; Marubeni Corporation participated in the logistics and procurement, as well as organizing financing from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, while JSC OGCC KazStroyService participated in construction and local procurement under SEG's leadership.   Then, on June 6, 2012, Atyrau Refinery LLP entered into a $1,130,408,642 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement (#BLA201201) with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured via Project ID#39556. The BCL bears interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 4.1% per annum and matures on November 6, 2025. China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure) provided $1.7 billion USD of buyer’s credit insurance (covering the loan loan principal and interest). The BCL received an official guarantee from the Government of Kazakhstan’s Ministry of Finance. JSC NC “KazMunayGas” also provided a guarantee for the loan. As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.1 billion. Atyrau Refinery LLP fully repaid the loan -- through a $604 milllion prepayment -- ahead of schedule in January 2022.    Then, on October 15, 2012, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) entered into a $199.5 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured via Project ID#54798. The PBC's maturity date was October 15, 2025, and it carried an interest rate of 3% per annum. This loan agreement was amended on October 30, 2014; however, the terms of the revision are unknown. Nor is it clear if DBK on-lent the proceeds of the PBC loan to Atyrau Refinery LLP. As of June 30, 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the PBC loan was $179.5 million. The total cost of the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project was $1,679,892,000.52.   It was also financed by a $251,983,878 loan dated on August 17, 2012 (№DBZI 241-E / 05-01) from the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC, a $297,500,000 loan dated August 8, 2012 from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), and three loans dated July 27, 2012, November 13, 2012, and December 29, 2012 that collectively amounted to ₸20,790,000 KZT from JSC KazMunayGaz - Refining and Marketing. The loans also covered commissions for arranging loans and insurance premia. The loans from Eximbank, JBIC (which may have involved the Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd.), and DBK were all guaranteed by JSC NC “KazMunayGas”. Sinopec subsidiary Sinopec Luoyang Engineering Co., Ltd. was involved in the implementation of the project.   Atyrau Refinery is one of the largest refineries in Kazakhstan and in 2011 refined 100,000 bbl of crude oil every day. The project sought to increase the productivity of Atyrau Refinery to 5.5 million tons per year and oil refining efficiency to 87%, gaining the yield of motor fuel up to 77%, corresponding to the international standards of Euro-4 and Euro-5. The project included the construction of 12 individual process units, a main facility with a catalytic cracking unit, designed for the conversion by delayed coking of the atmospheric distillation residues, heavy gas oil, vacuum gas oil and heavy gas oil into liquified petroleum gas, gasoline, and light cracking gas oil. The complex was set to include LPG desulfurization facilities, oligomerization, a naphtha hydro-treating unit, a gasoline and gas oil catalytic cracking unit, hydrogen production, isomerization units, etc.   The project's groundbreaking ceremony was held on September 10, 2012. It was expected that the implementation period would be 41 months (41 months from the groundbreaking ceremony was February 2016) and that construction would be completed in 2016. The turnkey project was formally handed over to the project owner on May 30, 2019. Then, in January 2020, Atyrau Refinery LLP received a long-term, tenge-denominated loan worth 46 billion tenge from DBK to refinance its loan from China Eximbank for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project.
staff_comments: 1. The average 6-month LIBOR in June 2012 was 0.736%. Therefore, the all-in interest rate was coded as 0.736% + 4.1%, or 4.836%. 2. The Chinese project title is 哈萨克斯坦阿特劳炼油厂石油项目. 3. AidData suspects that the PBC captured via Project ID#54798 partially financed DBK's earlier $251,983,878 USD loan dated on August 17, 2012 (№DBZI 241-E / 05-01); while the PBC came two months after this loan, DBK may have issued it knowing that China Eximbank would soon provide finance. If this is the case, it would explain why the project cost was reported as $1,679,892,000.52 despite the existence of this loan, which would have otherwise substantially increased the amount of financing. However, as stated earlier, it is unclear if this PBC was used by DBK to on-lend; this is merely informed speculation. 4. The $1.13 billion China Eximbank BCL to Atyrau Refinery LLP for the Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Construction Project is separate from the $884 million USD China Eximbank loan to Atyrau Refinery LLP for the Aromatic Hydrocarbons Complex Construction Project (see Project ID#54066). 5. It is very likely that the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project was funded through the $3.5 billion restricted portion of the Master Loan Facility (MLF) that China Eximbank issued to the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (as captured via Project ID#54797).
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
China Eximbank provides $1.13 billion buyer’s credit for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#54798, #54797 and #85185)

# Description
On December 29, 2011, Atyrau Refinery LLP — a project company and subsidiary of Kazakh state-owned KazMunayGas — signed an EPC turnkey contract for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project (also known as the Advanced Oil Refining Complex Construction Project and the Deeper Oil Conversion Complex Construction Project) with a consortium of contractors consisting of Sinopec Engineering Group (SEG), Marubeni Corporation, and JSC OGCC KazStroyService. SEG was the leader of the consortium; Marubeni Corporation participated in the logistics and procurement, as well as organizing financing from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, while JSC OGCC KazStroyService participated in construction and local procurement under SEG's leadership.   Then, on June 6, 2012, Atyrau Refinery LLP entered into a $1,130,408,642 buyer’s credit loan (BCL) agreement (#BLA201201) with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured via Project ID#39556. The BCL bears interest at a rate of six-month LIBOR plus 4.1% per annum and matures on November 6, 2025. China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure) provided $1.7 billion USD of buyer’s credit insurance (covering the loan loan principal and interest). As of December 31, 2017, the outstanding principal amount under this loan was $1.1 billion. Atyrau Refinery LLP fully repaid the loan -- through a $604 milllion prepayment -- ahead of schedule in January 2022.    Then, on October 15, 2012, the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC (DBK) entered into a $199.5 million preferential buyer’s credit (PBC) loan agreement with the Export-Import Bank of China for the Construction of Advanced Oil Refining Center at the Atyrau Refinery, as captured via Project ID#54798. The PBC's maturity date was October 15, 2025, and it carried an interest rate of 3% per annum. This loan agreement was amended on October 30, 2014; however, the terms of the revision are unknown. Nor is it clear if DBK on-lent the proceeds of the PBC loan to Atyrau Refinery LLP. As of June 30, 2017, the aggregate principal amount outstanding under the PBC loan was $179.5 million. The total cost of the KazMunayGas Atyrau Refinery Project was $1,679,892,000.52.   It was also financed by a $251,983,878 loan dated on August 17, 2012 (№DBZI 241-E / 05-01) from the Development Bank of Kazakhstan JSC, a $297,500,000 loan dated August 8, 2012 from the Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), and three loans dated July 27, 2012, November 13, 2012, and December 29, 2012 that collectively amounted to ₸20,790,000 KZT from JSC KazMunayGaz - Refining and Marketing. The loans also covered commissions for arranging loans and insurance premia. The loans from Eximbank, JBIC (which may have involved the Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ, Ltd.), and DBK were all guaranteed by JSC NC “KazMunayGas”. Sinopec subsidiary Sinopec Luoyang Engineering Co., Ltd. was involved in the implementation of the project.   Atyrau Refinery is one of the largest refineries in Kazakhstan and in 2011 refined 100,000 bbl of crude oil every day. The project sought to increase the productivity of Atyrau Refinery to 5.5 million tons per year and oil refining efficiency to 87%, gaining the yield of motor fuel up to 77%, corresponding to the international standards of Euro-4 and Euro-5. The project included the construction of 12 individual process units, a main facility with a catalytic cracking unit, designed for the conversion by delayed coking of the atmospheric distillation residues, heavy gas oil, vacuum gas oil and heavy gas oil into liquified petroleum gas, gasoline, and light cracking gas oil. The complex was set to include LPG desulfurization facilities, oligomerization, a naphtha hydro-treating unit, a gasoline and gas oil catalytic cracking unit, hydrogen production, isomerization units, etc.   The project's groundbreaking ceremony was held on September 10, 2012. It was expected that the implementation period would be 41 months (41 months from the groundbreaking ceremony was February 2016) and that construction would be completed in 2016. The turnkey project was formally handed over to the project owner on May 30, 2019. Then, in January 2020, Atyrau Refinery LLP received a long-term, tenge-denominated loan worth 46 billion tenge from DBK to refinance its loan from China Eximbank for the KazMunayGas Atyrau Oil Refinery Construction Project.
justification: Primary purpose is construction of oil refining infrastructure, increasing fossil fuel production capacity
evidence: Construction of advanced oil refining center, 12 process units including catalytic cracking and hydrogen production, focus on increasing oil refining efficiency and motor fuel yield
